title: Test your knowledge
description: A small prototype quiz for Responsible Research Metrics

options.text: to demonstrate that you publish in top journals
options.feedback: 'Top journals' is subjective and can't be used as a proxy for the quality of individual research.

options.text: to support statements that you make about your research
options.feedback: Good — metrics can help evidence statements if used responsibly.

options.text: to identify which of your research outputs is generating the most interest and engagement
options.feedback: Yes — metrics such as captures and altmetrics can indicate attention and engagement.

options.text: as a replacement for expert judgement or qualitative assessment
options.feedback: Incorrect — metrics should not replace qualitative expert judgement.

questions.explainCorrect: Metrics are useful as evidence, not a replacement for judgement. Use them with transparency and context.

questions.text: Using more than one type of metric to assess research is considered to be good practice because...

options.text: it reduces the risk of bias
options.feedback: Yes — multiple lenses reduce bias from single indicators.

options.text: it offers a more robust assessment
options.feedback: Correct — multiple metrics can offer a fuller picture.

options.text: it means that you don't need to provide qualitative assessment
options.feedback: Wrong — metrics complement qualitative assessment, but don't replace it.

questions.explainCorrect: Use a combination of indicators alongside qualitative statements for robust assessment.

questions.text: Is this statement true or false: "a Journal's Impact Factor is an accurate indicator of the quality of someone's research"?

options.text: true
options.feedback: No — JIF is about the journal, not an individual article or a researcher.

options.text: false
options.feedback: Correct — impact factor is not an accurate proxy for individual quality.

questions.explainCorrect: Use article-level metrics and evidence rather than journal-level proxies where assessing a researcher.

questions.text: Which of these is the best description of a normalised metric?

options.text: it measures the online attention and engagement that research outputs receive
options.feedback: This describes altmetrics, not normalisation.

options.text: it is a simple count of the number of citations a paper has received
options.feedback: This is a citation count rather than a normalised metric.

options.text: it is based on the highest number of papers produced that have the same number of citations
options.feedback: This is more like h-index; not a normalised metric.

options.text: A calculation the provider makes that allows for comparison of papers that are different ages and disciplines
options.feedback: Correct — normalised metrics account for age or discipline differences.

questions.explainCorrect: Normalised metrics (e.g., FWCI) allow fairer comparisons across disciplines and timeframes.

questions.text: What are some of the principles of metrics?

options.text: Transparency
options.feedback: Yes — being clear about methods, sources and dates is key.

options.text: Appropriateness
options.feedback: Correct — choose metrics appropriate to your question.

options.text: Responsible
options.feedback: This is the overarching aim — but principles are transparency, appropriateness, reproducible, equitable, and reassess.

options.text: Fixed
options.feedback: Metrics change; they aren’t fixed. This is not a principle.

questions.explainCorrect: Principles include transparency, appropriateness, reproducibility, equity, and continual reassessment.

questions.text: How could you make this statement better: "My article has been cited 40 times."

options.text: Give the date you took the metric
options.feedback: Yes — metrics are a snapshot; include the date.

options.text: Give the source you took the metric from
options.feedback: Yes — state where you got the count from (e.g., Scopus).

options.text: Give the date my article was published
options.feedback: This is helpful to interpret the citation count.

options.text: Give a journal metric
options.feedback: Using a journal metric here would be a proxy and not specific to the article.

questions.explainCorrect: Provide source and date and contextual info so the citation count is reproducible and contextualised.

questions.text: Is this statement true or false: "citations are always positive and mean everyone agrees with me"?

options.text: true
options.feedback: No — citations are not necessarily positive; they could indicate disagreement or critique.

options.text: false
options.feedback: Correct — citations do not always indicate agreement.

questions.explainCorrect: Citations can be positive, negative, or neutral; additional analysis is needed to understand meaning.

options.text: Take them on face value
options.feedback: Wrong — you should not take metrics without understanding context and calculation.

options.text: Read what the metric means and how it was calculated
options.feedback: Correct — always verify and understand the metric.

options.text: Never look at it again
options.feedback: Metrics update over time; re-check when making statements.

options.text: Provide context
options.feedback: Correct — provide context, sources and dates for metrics.

options.text: Have a question you want to answer
options.feedback: Correct — metrics should be chosen with a question in mind.

questions.explainCorrect: Understand, contextualise, and question the metrics — don’t rely on them blindly.

questions.text: Which article has performed better? Article A — Cited 12 times; Article B — Cited 13 times

options.text: Article A
options.feedback: Vague — citation count alone lacks context (age, discipline).

options.text: Article B
options.feedback: Vague — citation count alone lacks context (age, discipline).

options.text: I'm not sure - I need more info
options.feedback: Correct — you need more information such as age and discipline to judge fairly.

questions.explainCorrect: Citation counts alone are insufficient; consider context, normalisation and other indicators.
